Using nasapower to Create a Global Surface

Adam H. Sparks

2017-11-03

Creating a complete global surface of NASA - POWER data is easy using nasapower. However, the process is time-intensive since it requires many queries of the server.

Load libraries

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(nasapower)
library(raster)
library(viridis)

Set up

Using the raster package generate a raster object at 1˚ by 1˚ to represent one date of the NASA - POWER data.

x <- raster()

Get the lon/lat values from the x raster object to query from the NASA - POWER website.

xy <- data.frame(raster::xyFromCell(x, 1:64800))

Create a list of numeric vectors of lon/lat values for get_nasa() to use.

# Create a list of lonlat objects
xy_list <- split(xy, seq(nrow(xy)))

# Convert the list to numeric vectors for `get_nasa()`
xy_list <- lapply(xy_list, function(x) as.numeric(x))

Query the server

With the lon/lat values to provide to the get_nasa() function, we can now set up the data download.


surface <- purrr::map_df(
  .x = xy_list,
  .f = get_nasa,
  stdate = "2017-1-1",
  endate = "2017-1-1",
  vars = c("T2M", "RH2M")
  )

Map the data

Using ggplot2 it is possible to make simple maps of the data.

# Plot temperature
ggplot(surface, aes(x = LON, y = LAT, fill = T2M)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_viridis() +
  theme_bw() +
  coord_cartesian() +
  ggtitle("Average Temperature (˚C)")

# Plot RH
ggplot(surface, aes(x = LON, y = LAT, fill = RH2M)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_viridis(option = "C") +
  theme_bw() +
  coord_cartesian() +
  ggtitle("Relative Humidity (%)")
